Most cost-effective DOESN'T necessarily mean "do not purchase anything"; ok the solution in answer A, is the only costless one. But what about effectiveness? Using self-signed certificates for PUBLIC-FACING servers ??? 
A certificate works if and only if it is trusted by the user connecting to the server; that's why self-signed solution are normally adopted in LAN for INTERNAL use: as self-signed certificates are NOT issued by a trusted public CA they are NOT trusted by default; however, administrators, within the internal network, can use automated means to place copies of the self-signed certificate into the trusted root CA store for enterprise workstations; that works because all the users are internal users. But here we're dealing with PUBLIC-FACING servers so we have users connecting from all parts of the world! What should you do? Placing copies of your self-signed certificate on the devices of all the users in the world???

In my opinion the first option (A) is costless but also completely useless for public-facing server. I think, in this case the best option is C, purchase a wildcard certificate (that means just one certificate for all subdomains).
